%matplotlib inline
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import seaborn as sns
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
from scipy import stats
youtube = pd.read_csv('Data/youtube-new/USvideos.csv')

youtube = youtube.drop(['video_id','thumbnail_link','comments_disabled','ratings_disabled','video_error_or_removed','description','comment_count','trending_date','category_id','publish_time'], axis=1)

source: youtube
caps_title = pd.DataFrame(youtube['title'].values.tolist()).stack().str.split(expand=True).stack().str.isupper().sum()
print (caps_title)
tag_count = youtube['tags'].str.count('\|') + 1
youtube['tag_count'] = tag_count
plt.scatter(youtube['tag_count'],youtube['views'])
print()

# What is the data saying?

Looking at the youtube trending dataset, we try to explore what makes a good trending youtube video. Why are these part of the US trending list over any other youtube video. I tried seeing what was common throughout the data even across the different trending categories of youtube videos. Trying to see what would make any youtube video a trending youtube video. 

Now with something as complex as 'What makes a youtube video a trending youtube video?', we are trying to simplify the concept and generalize it. That way we can do simple testing to see how to make any youtube video into a trending youtube video.

One thing that stuck out or seemed common across the videos was the number of tags the video creator added. Let's explore a little of what a tag does and how it could help youtube videos make it to the trending list.

# What are 'tags'?

We will use the definition of youtube video tags from this [website](https://backlinko.com/hub/youtube/tags). 
> Video tags (also known as “YouTube tags”) are words and phrases used to give YouTube context about a video.

So the youtube video tags, or 'tags' for short, are phrases used to explain a bit about a video. Now this is different from a description in the sense that they are 'unseen'. They are almost like metadata.
>Metadata is a set of data that describes and gives information about other data.

Tags are important because they are used in youtube's search engine. You know when you go searching for that one video of the dog barking at a reflection of himeself what do you type in the search bar. Probably words like 'dog', 'mirror', 'barking', 'dumb', etc. The tags for that video could very well be 'dog', 'mirror', or 'barking'. This is a smart way to make sure your video pops up when someone is searching for that video. 

The article referenced above mentioned how youtube uses these tags to prioritize videos not only in the search engine but on the trending list. This goes to show a little more about the important of tags. But how tags is too many and how many is too few.

# Research Proposal

This research proposal will allow us to test one question about trending youtube videos: 'Will adding below average number of tags grant more views on a youtube video?' 

Now before we dive into the rollout plan of this experiment, we will analyze our research question to gain parameters for our experiment.

## Research Question Analysis

A few questions we must answer in this analysis for the experiment inlcude
* How much is an below average number of tags?
* What is the average number of tags?
* what is the number of views should we be expecting?
* What kind of tags should be part of the experiment?

### Benchmark Numbers

We will base benchmark numbers on the US Youtube trending data set referenced above. We will only be using the top 2500 videos with the most views.
#Filter dataset for top 2500 videos
top = youtube.nlargest(2500, ['views'])

source: top

outputs.name: stdout
text:
Average Number of Tags:
19.0
Average Number of Views:
21090379.0

source:
#Calculate the average number of tags across the entire Youtube dataset
print('Average Number of Tags:')
print(np.round(np.mean(top['tag_count']), decimals=0))
#Calculate the average number of views across the entire Youtube dataset
print('Average Number of Views:')
print(np.round(np.mean(top['views']), decimals=0))

Looking at the data, it seems that the average number of tags on the trending Youtube list is 19 tags. Also, the average number of views for these videos is roughly 2.1 million views. Now this great for understanding where our control group benchmarks should be at. But now we need to understand where we should place the testing benchmarks.

outputs.name: stdout
text:
One Standard Deviation Below the Mean (Tags):
7.0

source:
#Calculate 1 standard deviations from the mean of number of tags
tag_mean = np.mean(top['tag_count'])
tag_std = np.std(top['tag_count'])
print('One Standard Deviation Below the Mean (Tags):')
print(np.round(tag_mean - tag_std, decimals=0))

We can see that going one standard deviation below the mean for the number of tags we get a test benchmark of 7 tags. The reason I chose to go one standard devation from the mean in setting the benchmark for the number of tags on the test group, is that this allows a more caculated approach to the experiment. This will allow us to further test in the future potentially based on two standard deviations or minus standard deviations. 

Now that we have some benchmarks to base our experiment on we can continue to analyzing the hypothesis. 
> Decreasing the number of tags on a video will lead to an increase in views.

#A simple scatterplot to see the relationship of tags versus views
plt.scatter(top['tag_count'],top['views'])
plt.axvline(x=19, color='red')
plt.axvline(x=7, color='green')
print()

Looking at the graph above seems to confirm our suspicion of the hypothesis. As the control benchmark (red) of 19 tags seems to have more videos with less views surrounding. Versus the test benchmark (green) of 7 seems to have more videos with more views surrounding. Now as this is just visually seeing the trend, will the test show us the same results and will they be significant.

## Research Plan

### Analysis Plan

1. Create two similar youtube videos (videos must attract a simliar population)
2. Create a plan of release to be during either the same time or similar time periods
    * avoid holidays, or culturally important time periods
3. For video A generate 19 tags based on random word choice
    * word choice will be based on nouns used in the video itself (if a cooking video words are mostly associated with cooking terms)
4. Publish Video on Youtube
5. After 1 month calculate how many views video A attained, and also the ratio of likes to dislikes
6. For video B generate 7 tags based on same random word choice as in video A
7. Publish video B on Youtube
8. After 1 month calculate how many views video B attained, and also the ratio of likes to dislikes

### Benchmarks
Experiment Benchamrks:
Time for videos to gather views: 1 month
Metrics:
* Number of views
* Ratio of likes to dislikes

Control Benchmarks:
Number of tags: 19

Test Benchmarks:
Number of tags: 7

We are only gathering metric data for 1 month as this gives enough time for the video to be noticed by the public, but too much where we may run into a extreme circumstance that may increase views unexpectedly. We are also gathering the ratio of likes to dislikes, to gather potential insight as to how the video was received by the public.

### Bias Prevention

* The videos are too different and are received by two different populations
    * keep the catergory of the videos the same
    * make the content similar in creative design
* The time periods the videos are realeased should also be similar and not have extraordinary events 
    * potentially release the videos during March and April
* Make sure that the tags for the videos are randomly generated
    * adding any human input to the tag generation may lead to implicit bias
    * pull all the nouns used in the video and randomly pick tags from noun list

## Final Thoughts

With this experiment there are details that are unpredictable. As with any video, or internet sensation, virality is unpredictable what may be viral content one day may not be the next. Controlling for all conditions to be perfect in any experiment is impossible but can lead to meaningful results none the less. 

There are two ways to analyze the results of the test. One would be to compare the results significance against each test (A & B). Another is to compare the results of B to the Youtube trending list. THe latter may not be a good indication of succes in the experiment as the videos in testing may or may not the trending list or be at that standard. None the less the ratio of likes to dislikes can be compared across all datasets, as the ratio tells more about the population reaction rather popularity of video.

Moving forward, considering running this test at different levels of testing benchmarks. Perhaps testing the number of tags 2 standard deviation below the mean or above the mean by 1 or 2 standard deviations. Lastly, I cannot reiterate the importance of the culture behind virality. For years, Youtubers have worked to always make viral content and almost all them have said that to make a viral video you can check all the boxes, but there is always a x-factor that is never known and it could make or break the virality of a video.
